newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: MANY CZECHS IGNORE SENATE ELECTIONS - SURVEY.
newsitem.headline: MANY CZECHS IGNORE SENATE ELECTIONS - SURVEY.

text.p: Czechs are uninspired by the prospect of electing their first Senators later this month, according to an opinion poll forecasting low voter turnout and showing an ignorance of pre-election campaigns.

A survey by the state-funded research agency IVVM showed 57 percent of potential voters expected to cast a ballot in the first round of the elections on November 15-16, and only 52 percent said they would vote in runoffs a week later.
The early-October survey of a scientific sample of 1,365 Czechs said 46 percent of citizens did not know whether there was an election campaign or not.
"There is, in general, low interest in the elections and the willingness to vote is low," Eliska Rendlova, an analyst at IVVM told Reuters. "A part of the public even rejects having the Senate."
A previous IVVM poll showed that 53 percent of Czechs have doubts about the necessity of a second house of parliament.

The elections will be the first for the newly-created upper house of parliament which will have limited legislative power but will primarily act as an advisory body to the lower house, the Chamber of Deputies.
Voter turnout in the lower house elections was 76.41 percent, although surveys had suggested more than 80 percent planned to vote.

Analysts still are watching the Senate elections, which are based on a first-past-the-post system in 81 constituencies, as the first political test since June elections to the lower house stripped the centre-right government of its majority.

Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus's Civic Democratic Party (ODS), and the leading opposition Social Democrats (CSSD) are seen sending the most candidates into the final round of the two-step Senate elections, another survey, by an independent agency Factum showed earlier this week.

If no candidate in a constituency gets over 50 percent of votes cast in the first round, there is a second round with the top two candidates from the first poll, and analysts widely beleive that most races will go to two rounds.
The new survey showed only 25 percent beleived there was an election campaign underway.
